item.title: Sri Lanka Live Updates: Tear Gas Fired at Crowd at Prime Minister’s Office
item.description: Protesters tried to push through the gates of the office. His spokesman said that he expects to be sworn in to replace President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, who fled the country early on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times

item.title: Russia Reaches Out to Iran for Help in Countering West
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will visit Tehran next week, along with the leader of Turkey. But competition in oil markets reflects a complicated new landscape.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers taking a break at a compound not far from the front lines in the Donetsk region on Monday.

item.title: Mission Impossible? Officials Wrangle to Free Ukraine’s Grains
item.description: Locked in talks for months with little success, negotiators are set to meet in Istanbul on Wednesday. Failure could intensify a food crisis already being felt around the world.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grain bins storing corn, wheat, sunflower and soybeans on the grounds of the Agro-Region facility in Boryspil, Ukraine in May.

item.title: In Divide Over Ukraine, China Stakes a Position Further From U.S.
item.description: Recent statements have underscored the deep chasms in a relationship that is getting worse, as the Biden administration tries to come up with a cohesive China policy.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Stefani Reynolds
item.media:description: China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, and U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Bali, Indonesia, last week.

item.title: Fake Indian Cricket League Swindles Russian Gamblers
item.description: The bats and balls were real, but not much else was authentic in what officials said was an elaborate scheme to dupe Russian gamblers through hoax games streamed on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Robert Cianflone/Getty Images
item.media:description: A real Indian Premier League match between the Mumbai Indians and the Chennai Super Kings in Hyderabad, India, in 2019.

item.title: Is the World Really Falling Apart, or Does It Just Feel That Way?
item.description: By most measures — with one glaring exception — people around the world are better off than ever. So why doesn’t it feel that way, especially to Americans?
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

item.title: Mo Farah Documentary Puts Spotlight on U.K.’s Hard-line Policy
item.description: Experts hope the running star’s revelations will humanize migrants’ struggles, but they don’t expect policy changes in a country that is trying to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Kirsty Wigglesworth/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mo Farah celebrating winning the men’s 10,000-meter final at the 2016 Summer Olympics.

item.title: History Haunts Ukraine’s Undiplomatic Voice in Berlin
item.description: Debate over a Ukrainian nationalist leader’s role in the Holocaust has exposed how views of the past shape European allies’ relationships with Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: John Macdougall/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Andriy Melnyk, second from right, at a World War II commemoration in Berlin in May. As Germany’s ambassador to Ukraine, he became a provocative favorite on the talk show circuit.

item.title: Ailing Hong Kong Activist Defiant as Court Sentences Him to Prison
item.description: Koo Sze-yiu, who has been diagnosed with late-stage colon cancer, was sentenced to nine months in prison for planning a protest, amid fears he could die in prison.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Kin Cheung/Associated Press
item.media:description: The pro-democracy protester Koo Sze-yiu, center, carrying a mock coffin during a demonstration in Hong Kong, in 2019.

item.title: Dangerous Heat Wave Strikes China
item.description: Parts of the east and south withered under extreme temperatures, even as health workers in hazmat suits persisted in a round of mandatory coronavirus tests.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Some people escaped the heat in an air-raid shelter in Nanjing, China, but animals in the zoo, and health workers doing coronavirus tests, were not so lucky.

item.title: In West Africa and Beyond, Mali’s Famed Manuscripts Are Put to Use
item.description: Tens of thousands of manuscripts were smuggled out of Timbuktu under jihadists’ noses, containing a wealth of knowledge about science, governance and peace-making. Now the public is getting a look.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Nicolas Réméné for The New York Times
item.media:description: A manuscript in its conservation box.

item.title: Biden Meets With Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador
item.description: The White House meeting between President Biden and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador was intended to help shore up a critical relationship.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Chris Kleponis
item.media:description: President Biden met with President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Putin’s Oil War With the West Comes at His Allies’ Expense
item.description: Russia’s use of energy as a weapon in its standoff with the West is redrawing the geopolitical map, but it could strain ties with allies like Iran and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil tanker anchored at docks in Venezuela in 2021.

item.title: Biden Mideast Trip Fraught With Political Perils
item.description: President Biden is heading to the Mideast with one eye on U.S. strategic goals abroad and another on his political vulnerabilities back home.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden embarked on a visit to the Middle East on Tuesday night.

item.title: Protesters March in Sri Lanka After President Flees Country
item.description: Security forces fired tear gas in an effort to disperse people. Families with young children were among those marching.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sri Lankans lined up Tuesday to get inside the president’s residence, which was taken over by protesters.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s oil war with the West.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil tanker anchored at docks in Venezuela in 2021. A longtime ally of the Kremlin, Venezuela has had to sharply discount its crude exports as Russia has turned to new buyers for its own oil.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Parliament Holds Key to Who Will Lead Next
item.description: The spotlight is now on a parliament that has long frustrated the island nation of 22 million, with lawmakers and political parties engaging in protracted and messy fights over positions of power.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Special Task Force personnel guard near the Parliament building in Colombo, Sri Lanka in May.

item.title: European Space Agency Cuts Ties With Russia on Its Mars Mission
item.description: Washington and Moscow are continuing to work together on the International Space Station.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Aoes Medialab M.Thiebaut/European Space Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An artist’s rendition of the ESA ExoMars robot on Mars.

item.title: Putin, Looking for Allies, Plans to Meet Leaders of Turkey and Iran
item.description: In his second diplomatic push since Russia invaded Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin will travel to Tehran to build bridges between leaders at odds over Syria, oil and the West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: Wave of Repression Spreads in Iran Against Artists and Dissidents
item.description: Three filmmakers were arrested, as well as a politician and several family members of people killed in anti-government protests.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Mohammad Rasolouf and Mostafa Aleahmad, two filmmakers who were arrested in Iran, in a photograph provided by colleagues.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Extreme Heat Grips China
item.description: Plus the conviction of an ailing Hong Kong activist and President Vladimir Putin’s upcoming trip to Iran.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Aly Song/Reuters
item.media:description: A woman used a fan during a heat wave in Shanghai on Tuesday.

item.title: C.D.C. Still Unprepared to Respond Quickly to Global Travel Threats, U.S. Audit Finds
item.description: A new report exposes the outdated data collection methods still relied on by the public health agency.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Mohamed Sadek for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York’s LaGuardia Airport on July 2. A new report found that the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s system for gathering data for contact tracing “needs substantial improvement.”

item.title: U.S. Military Says Senior ISIS Leader in Syria Killed in Drone Strike
item.description: The attack was the latest in a series of American operations against ISIS and Al Qaeda in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Bakr Alkasem/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A crater from a drone strike in Syria on Tuesday. The attack was the latest of several American military operations against ISIS and Al Qaeda in Syria.

item.title: Putin and Erdogan to Talk in Tehran, Spotlighting Complicated Relationship
item.description: The meetings in Iran also position Turkey as a key mediator between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Denis Doyle/Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, which shares the Black Sea coast with both Russia and Ukraine. He has emerged as one of the most active mediators between their leaders.

item.title: Pandemic Remains a Global Health Emergency, W.H.O. Says
item.description: “Covid-19 is nowhere near over,” the agency’s director general declared.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coronavirus vaccination clinic in San Juan, P.R., in May.

item.title: Manchin, Playing to the Home Crowd, Is Fighting Electric Cars to the End
item.description: The West Virginia senator, who holds the swing vote in negotiations for a budget plan, wants to cut incentives. The president and most Senate Democrats say buyer credits are crucial to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Joe Manchin III and other leaders from West Virginia want the federal government to invest billions of dollars to create a “hydrogen hub” in their state.

item.title: War Has Russia Jockeying With Venezuela and Iran for Oil Buyers.
item.description: The competition for buyers is setting off a price war that could hurt them all.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela. Russia’s efforts to find new buyers for its oil has forced Venezuela and Iran to discount their crude.

item.title: U.N. Yields to Russia’s Limits on Aid Mission in Syria
item.description: Just days earlier, the U.N. Security Council had failed to agree to continue humanitarian assistance to four million Syrians in Idlib Province, after Russia vetoed plans to extend it for one year.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Francisco Seco/Associated Press
item.media:description: A camp for displaced people run by the Turkish Red Crescent in Samada District, north of Idlib, Syria.

item.title: Ukraine Reports Strike on Russian Ammunition Depot in Kherson Region
item.description: A pro-Russia official said the weapon used was a High Mobility Artillery Rocket System, or HIMARS. The truck-mounted, multiple-rocket launchers are the most advanced weapons so far supplied by the United States to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Planet Labs PBC, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A satellite image released by Planet Labs PBC on Tuesday showed a crater where a missile appears to have struck in Nova Kakhovka, Ukraine.

item.title: After a Pandemic Hiatus, the Bulls Are Running Again in Pamplona
item.description: The running of the bulls, the highlight of the San Fermín Festival in Pamplona, returned to the Spanish city for the first time since 2019. So did thousands of thrill-seekers.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Francheska Melendez
item.media:credit: Jose Jordan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: London’s Heathrow Airport Says It Will Limit Passengers
item.description: Facing staff shortages that have significantly constrained capacity, the airport’s chief executive asked airlines to stop selling tickets until September.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Like many other airports this summer, Heathrow in London has been plagued by long lines.

item.title: Considering the Legacy of Shinzo Abe, On the Day of His Funeral
item.description: On the day of his funeral service, we consider the full legacy of Japan’s longest-serving prime minister.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kimimasa Mayama/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A tribute to Shinzo Abe, Japan’s longest-serving prime minister.

item.title: Italy Drought in Po River Basin Tightens Its Grip
item.description: A prolonged dry spell caused by increasingly dry winters, higher temperatures and less rain has put the fertile region’s rice harvest and other crops at risk.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Po River at Linarolo, south of Milan, this month. The waterway, Italy’s longest, has dwindled to a trickle in some areas.

item.title: Ukraine’s Demands for More Weapons Clash With U.S. Concerns
item.description: Pulling Ukrainians out of battle to train them could accelerate Russia’s gains, officials say. The Pentagon is also monitoring the levels of its own stockpiles.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Some officials are concerned that pulling too many Ukrainian artillery specialists off the front lines could weaken Ukrainian defenses.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s strikes on Ukrainian civilians.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainain soldiers salvaging parts from a Russian armoured vehicle. The British military recently estimated the number of dead Russians at 25,000.

item.title: Russia Steps Up Attacks on Civilian Areas, Even With Advance Paused
item.description: Russian forces in eastern Ukraine are regrouping, with a new offensive expected, but they continue to rain death and destruction on cities and towns.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Kamila Hrabchuk and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents tried to extinguish a fire minutes after rockets hit a residential area in Bakhmut on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Is Getting Iran to Send Hundreds of Drones, White House Says
item.description: The national security adviser said the U.S. believed Iran was preparing to train Russian troops imminently.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, said on Monday that Russia is seeking surveillance drones from Iran to use against Ukraine.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Bank Protests in China
item.description: Plus Ukrainian civilians bear the brunt of Russia’s war and new details after Shinzo Abe’s death.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Rivals Vying to Replace Johnson Are Diverse in Background, Not in Plans
item.description: The Conservatives running to be Britain’s prime minister include women and people of non-European descent, but they sound a lot alike: They like Brexit and want to cut taxes.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: John Sibley/Reuters
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, who resigned as chancellor of the Exchequer, is a contender for prime minister.

item.title: Cambridge Opens an Inquiry After Student Deaths
item.description: One of the deaths is confirmed to have been suicide and the others are suspected of being suicides. The university is working with the National Health Service to investigate.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cambridge University’s King’s College last year.

item.title: Webb Space Telescope: Biden and NASA Reveal First Image
item.description: From the White House on Monday, humanity got its first glimpse of what the observatory in space has been seeing: a cluster of early galaxies.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye, Kenneth Chang and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: NASA, ESA, CSA, and STScI
item.media:description: The Webb telescope’s image of the galaxy cluster SMACS 0723 includes thousands of galaxies, including the faintest objects ever observed in infrared. The light from SMACS 0723 in this image is 4.6 billion years old.

item.title: Putin Extends Fast-Track Russian Citizenship Process to All Ukrainians
item.description: The move indicated that Russia might seek to establish permanent control of Ukrainian territories currently occupied by Moscow’s forces.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A Migration Service office offering Russian passports to local residents, in Donetsk, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: Ukrainian Medic’s Months in Russian Cell: Cold, Dirty and Used as a Prop
item.description: Yulia Paievska was already well known in Ukraine when she was captured, but the trauma she describes has made her a symbol of bravery and sacrifice.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yulia Paievska in Kyiv, Ukraine, where she has been recuperating from months of Russian captivity.

item.title: E.U. Health Agency Recommends Second Covid Booster for Older People
item.description: Another shot is also recommended for those with underlying medical conditions as mounting cases and hospitalizations rise across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds at the Trocadéro near the Eiffel Tower in Paris, in May.

item.title: A hail of Russian strikes brings terror to Ukraine’s east.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Evgeniy Maloletka/Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescue workers putting out a fire in a destroyed car after a Russian attack on a residential neighborhood in downtown Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Three Cities in China Impose Partial Lockdowns and Macau Shuts Casinos
item.description: The cities of Xi’an, Lanzhou and Haikou set restrictions on several million residents. In Macau, the gambling hub, authorities shut casinos and ordered everyone to stay home.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: John Mak/Reuters
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing last week in Macau, whose 680,000 residents have been relatively sheltered from the virus.

item.title: Dueling Weaknesses
item.description: The Times has released its first poll of the 2022 midterm cycle.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden after a trip to Cleveland last week.

item.title: Where Mantras Trump Medicine, Vaccines Are a ‘Violation’
item.description: The Baduy, an Indigenous group in Indonesia, believe that vaccinations are impure, and unnecessary, and that their beliefs protect them. To skeptics, they note their Covid death toll: zero.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Ulet Ifansasti
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carrying durian fruit past rice barns on the way to the nearest market. All Baduy are taught to abide by the principle that the natural world is not to be harmed.

item.title: A Glimpse Inside a Florentine Silk-Weaving Workshop
item.description: The Antico Setificio Fiorentino, which relies on looms from the 18th and 19th centuries, has been producing precious textiles since 1786.
item.dc:creator: Susan Wright
item.media:credit: Susan Wright

item.title: A Year After Mass Protest, Cubans Face Stark Choice: ‘Prison or Exile’
item.description: Thousands of Cubans took to the streets last July protesting economic misery. A year later, hundreds are in jail and the financial crisis has only worsened.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alexandre Meneghini/Reuters
item.media:description: Plainclothes police officers clashing with antigovernment protesters last July 11 in Havana during the biggest wave of demonstrations since the Communist government took power.

item.title: ‘There’s Nothing’: Scarcity Deepens Desperation in Sri Lanka
item.description: The island nation was once an economic hope, with a growing middle class. Now many people are living on the edge, unable to buy even the basics.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line for fuel in May in Colombo, the capital. The government has imposed rationing, and motorists can wait for days to fill their tanks.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia seeks new soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainain soldiers salvaging parts from a Russian armoured vehicle. The British military recently estimated the number of dead Russians at 25,000.

item.title: Brittney Griner Is Honored by Fellow Players at W.N.B.A. All-Star Game
item.description: The league made Griner, who has been detained in Russia since February, an honorary starter for the game.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Shauntel Lowe
item.media:credit: Stacy Revere/Getty Images
item.media:description: The W.N.B.A. All-Stars wore matching jerseys with Brittney Griner’s number, 42, during the second half of the All-Star Game on Sunday.

item.title: War in Ukraine Could Have You Paying More For Hummus
item.description: Russia and Ukraine are two of the biggest exporters of chickpeas, and the global supply is expected to decline this year.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:credit: Valaurian Waller for The New York Times
item.media:description: The global supply of chickpeas may be reduced by as much as 20 percent this year because Russia and Ukraine are two of the world’s biggest exporters of the legume, according to a trade group.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Sri Lanka in Turmoil
item.description: Plus Shinzo Abe’s allies win a supermajority in Japan’s parliament and Russia bombards Donetsk.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Dinuka Liyanawatte/Reuters
item.media:description: Demonstrators protested inside the President’s House in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Saturday.

item.title: A survivor emerges from the rubble of an apartment complex.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Kamila Hrabchuk
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency crews working in Chasiv Yar, where Russian rockets struck an apartment complex.

item.title: Embattled Leaders in Hiding, Sri Lankans Ask: What’s Next?
item.description: Protesters in Sri Lanka roamed the halls and grounds of power without challenge as they waited to see who would take the reins of their economically devastated country.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Arun Sankar/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People crowding inside the presidential palace on Sunday.

item.title: In Ivory Coast, This Rainforest Is Both Refuge and Junkyard
item.description: An endangered gem of lush greenery in Abidjan, Ivory Coast’s economic hub, is at the center of government efforts to promote ecotourism. Those who live and work there worry about what it means for them.
item.media:credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: A highway separates Banco National Park from the sprawl of Abidjan, the economic hub of Ivory Coast.

item.title: What We Know About the Protests in Sri Lanka
item.description: Months of demonstrations over dire economic conditions culminated in a peaceful takeover of the presidential residence and promises of resignations.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Dinuka Liyanawatte/Reuters
item.media:description: Protesters at the residence of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka in the capital, Colombo, on Saturday.
